properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds will cause blowing snow this morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T18:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T09:20:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2018860447.2021
Area: Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, followed by ice pellets or freezing rain, is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: Bay St. George. Time span: continuing until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will transition to ice pellets and possibly freezing rain later tonight. Conditions will improve slightly Wednesday morning as the snow transitions to flurries. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T13:59:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T02:49:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2108929062.2021
Area: Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning Ended
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is no longer expected. ###

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values of approximately -38 are expected this morning. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T18:59:28-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values near minus 55 are expected to moderate by this afternoon. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T22:29:22-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional Snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum winds: northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h. Location: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Visibility is expected to be poor over some areas due to a combination of snow and blowing snow. Conditions will improve by late afternoon or early evening as snow tapers to flurries and winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T21:59:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T08:38:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2352375826.2021
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for overnight and this morning. Lake effect snow bands and heavy flurries will move into the region overnight and shift back and forth across the region through this morning giving variable amounts of snow. Local amounts of 5 to 10 centimetres of snow can be expected by this morning. The heavier bands of snow will likely move north of Sault Ste. Marie this morning. Travel may become hazardous at times overnight and this morning due to accumulating snow and slippery conditions. Visibility could locally be reduced at times in heavy flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T22:14:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T06:15:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2548322921.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: northern Avalon, Burin, and Connaigre Peninsulas, and northern sections of the southern Avalon. Time span: this morning. Remarks: Freezing rain will change to rain or drizzle this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T13:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T08:37:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2116544484.2021

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Additional rainfall: 10 mm. Time span: continuing this morning. Remarks: Rain will taper to drizzle this morning. Over northern portions of the southern Avalon, freezing rain early this morning will change to rain or drizzle. Significant snowmelt and runoff are likely to occur. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T17:59:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T08:38:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0376030070.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. Locations: Corner Brook and Gros Morne. Time span: continuing into this afternoon. Remarks: Snow and wind will combine to reduce visibility at times in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. Conditions will improve this afternoon as snow tapers off to flurries. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 60 may persist until Friday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls continue into the overnight. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T20:56:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T04:57:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1290380850.2021
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts to the lee of the Highlands: westerly 100 km/h. Time span: this morning until 9.00 AM. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T14:39:12-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Additional Snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum winds: east to northeast 40 gusting to 60 km/h. Location: the northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Visibility is expected to be poor, especially over exposed coastal communities, as snow combines with wind to produce blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve this evening as snow tapers off to flurries and winds begin to ease. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-18T00:39:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-17T08:40:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4029774173.2021
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls may intensify this evening off of Georgian Bay and continue tonight. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T15:21:51-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold early this morning. Very cold temperatures combined with light winds will give wind chill values near minus 40 early this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T17:09:24-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for early this morning. Travel conditions will once again become hazardous early this morning due to accumulating snow and local blowing snow and will continue into the afternoon. An additional 5 cm of snow will be possible. Motorists are advised to take care on the roads as the snow starts to accumulate once again. Slow down and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T17:40:22-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are moving in off of Lake Huron and will likely continue this evening and persist overnight. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible with highest accumulations likely near Lake Huron. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
